**Mikhail Kalashnikov's Legacy: A Life of Guilt and Redemption**

Mikhail Kalashnikov, the inventor of the iconic AK-47 assault rifle, left behind a complex legacy before his death at the age of 94. In a letter written to the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill, Kalashnikov expressed his deep spiritual pain and guilt over the countless lives lost due to his invention. The letter, dated May 2012, was published by Izvestia, a pro-Kremlin daily, and reveals a man grappling with the moral implications of his creation.

Kalashnikov designed the AK-47 in 1947, inspired by his experiences in World War II, where he was wounded fighting for the Red Army. The rifle's simplicity, reliability, and affordability made it a widely used and manufactured weapon, with over 100 million sold worldwide. However, its use by terrorists, child soldiers, and other malicious actors has led to widespread suffering and death.

In his letter, Kalashnikov questioned whether he was responsible for the lives lost, despite his intention to design the rifle to defend his country. He wrote, "My spiritual pain is unbearable. I keep having the same unsolved question: if my rifle took away people's lives, then can it be that I... am guilty for people's deaths, even if they were enemies?" The letter is signed with a wavering hand, suggesting that Kalashnikov may have had assistance in writing it, possibly from a priest.

Kalashnikov's conversion to Christianity at the age of 91, and his baptism, may have contributed to his spiritual introspection. His daughter, Yelena, acknowledged that her father was not a devout Christian, but rather a product of his generation.

The Russian Orthodox Church responded to Kalashnikov's letter, with Patriarch Kirill's press secretary, Alexander Volkov, stating that the Church supports the creators and soldiers who use weapons to protect the Fatherland. Kalashnikov's funeral was attended by President Vladimir Putin, a testament to his enduring legacy in Russia.

Kalashnikov's life and legacy serve as a reminder of the complex moral implications of innovation and the responsibility that comes with creating something that can be used for both good and evil. His story highlights the need for introspection and self-reflection, even in the face of great success and recognition.

"I have no regrets and bear no responsibility for how politicians have used it." It turns out "no regrets" might not have exactly been true. The AFP picks up a report from Russia's Izvestia that Kalashnikov penned a letter to the head of the Russian Orthodox Church nine months before his December death in which he wrote of "unbearable ... spiritual pain" and asked about his culpability. It contains this line: "I keep having the same unsolved question: if my rifle took away people's lives, then can it be that I ... am guilty for people's deaths, even if they were enemies?" AFP notes that Izvestia ran a copy of the letter, which is typed on Kalashnikov's personal stationery and signed "with a wavering hand." A rep for Patriarch Kirill confirms that the letter was sent, and says the church leader wrote a reply—one that very may well have calmed his fears. Says the rep, "The Church has a very definite position: when weapons serve to protect the Fatherland, the Church supports both its creators and the soldiers who use it." **Man Convicted in 1957 Cold Case Released from Prison After New Evidence Emerges**

A 76-year-old man, Jack McCullough, has been released from prison after a judge ordered a new trial in the 1957 cold case of the abduction and murder of 7-year-old Maria Ridulph. McCullough, who was serving a life sentence, was convicted in 2012 of the crime, but a new review of evidence by DeKalb County State's Attorney Richard Schmack has raised doubts about his guilt.

Maria Ridulph was abducted on December 3, 1957, while playing in the snow with a friend in Sycamore, Illinois. Her body was found five months later, and the case went cold for decades. In 2011, McCullough was questioned and arrested, and a judge found him guilty after a week-long trial. However, Schmack, who was not involved in the original case, conducted a six-month review of the evidence and concluded that McCullough could not have committed the crime.

Schmack's review found that newly discovered phone records supported McCullough's alibi, which was that he was in Rockford, Illinois, attempting to enlist in the U.S. Air Force at the time of the abduction. The records showed that McCullough made a collect call to his parents at 6:57 p.m. from a phone booth in downtown Rockford, which is 40 miles northwest of where Maria was abducted. Schmack also reviewed police reports and hundreds of other documents, including from the Air Force recruitment office, which he said contained "a wealth of information pointing to McCullough's innocence, and absolutely nothing showing guilt."

The judge, William P. Brady, ordered McCullough's release, citing the new evidence and the fact that it was impossible for McCullough to have been in two places at once. McCullough's family was overjoyed by the decision, while Maria's family remains convinced of his guilt and has sought the appointment of a special prosecutor to keep him behind bars.

The case has been a source of controversy, with many questioning the original conviction and the reliability of the evidence used to convict McCullough. The case highlights the challenges of prosecuting cold cases, where evidence is often lost or destroyed, and memories fade over time.
answers: A man convicted four years ago in the oldest cold case ever tried was freed Friday after an Illinois judge vacated his conviction and subsequent life sentence, CNN reports. According to CBS News, 76-year-old Jack McCullough was convicted of kidnapping a 7-year-old girl, choking her, and stabbing her to death in 1957. The case was reopened in 2008, and McCullough was arrested in 2011 and convicted the following year. After an appeal by McCullough, Illinois state's attorney Richard Schmack launched a six-month investigation that found what he calls "clear and convincing evidence" that McCullough is innocent. While the judge Friday vacated McCullough's conviction, he stopped short of declaring him innocent, and a new trial will be held, the Chicago Tribune reports. McCullough, who lived in the same neighborhood as the kidnapped girl, says he was 40 miles away at an Air Force recruiting center at the time of the kidnapping. It's an alibi that passed a polygraph test in 1957 and made it impossible for him to be the culprit based on the FBI's original timeline for the kidnapping. That timeline was later changed by police, and Schmack says documents—including phone and Air Force records—supporting McCullough's alibi were wrongly not allowed at his trial. A friend of the kidnapped girl picked McCullough out of a photo lineup when the case was reopened. But his was the only non-yearbook photo in the lineup, and she picked a different man out of a photo lineup 50 years earlier. That info wasn't allowed at McCullough's trial either. No physical evidence was ever found to support McCullough's conviction.

**Cigarette Smoke Fuels the Growth of Superbugs: A Growing Concern**

Recent studies have revealed a disturbing link between cigarette smoke and the virulent rampage of superbugs, specifically Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Researchers at the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine have found that cigarette smoke not only harms human respiratory and immune cells but also makes MRSA more resistant to antibiotics and more aggressive in its invasion of human cells.

According to the studies, MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke extract becomes four times more resistant to macrophage killing and more resistant to antimicrobial peptides, which are essential for fighting off bacterial infections. The smoke-exposed bacteria also become better at invading human cells and can cause more severe infections, including pneumonia. In fact, the study found that MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke extract was able to kill more mice in lab cultures than those not exposed to smoke.

The researchers believe that cigarette smoke acts as an alarm to MRSA, warning it to activate its defenses and become more resistant to the immune system. This is a concerning finding, as MRSA is a type of bacteria that causes life-threatening infections to the skin, bloodstream, or surgical sites, and is often resistant to antibiotics.

The study also found that the increased resistance to the immune system continued for 24 hours after exposure to cigarette smoke, suggesting that it could be inherited. This is a significant concern, as MRSA can divide rapidly, generating nearly 17 million descendents in just 12 hours.

In contrast, e-cigarette vapor was found to have a lesser effect on MRSA, making it only slightly more aggressive but not as much as cigarette smoke. The study suggests that cigarette smoke makes the pathogen tougher, rather than just harming the smoker.

The findings of these studies highlight the importance of quitting smoking to prevent the spread of superbugs like MRSA. The researchers hope that their findings will add to the growing body of evidence that supports the need to avoid smoking and reduce the risk of infectious diseases.

**Key Findings:**

* Cigarette smoke makes MRSA more resistant to antibiotics and more aggressive in its invasion of human cells.
* MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke extract becomes four times more resistant to macrophage killing and more resistant to antimicrobial peptides.
* The increased resistance to the immune system continued for 24 hours after exposure to cigarette smoke.
* Cigarette smoke acts as an alarm to MRSA, warning it to activate its defenses and become more resistant to the immune system.
*
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

The researchers propose that the transition to the Middle Stone Age was driven by long-term climate change, which led to the development of more complex and mobile societies. The findings have significant implications for our understanding of human evolution and the development of modern human behavior. They suggest that the "human revolution" that made us modern never actually occurred, and that complex behaviors and technological innovations were present in multiple human species across Africa, rather than being a unique characteristic of our own species.

**Global Obesity Epidemic: A Growing Concern**

A recent study published in the Lancet medical journal has revealed a staggering 2.1 billion people worldwide are either obese or overweight, accounting for nearly 30% of the global population. The study, conducted by the University of Washington's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, analyzed data from 188 countries over 33 years, from 1980 to 2013. The findings indicate that obesity is a growing problem worldwide, affecting both rich and poor nations, and is no longer a malady of developed countries alone.

**Key Statistics:**

* 2.1 billion people worldwide are either obese or overweight, a 28% increase in adults and 47% increase in children over the past 33 years.
* The number of overweight and obese people has risen from 857 million in 1980 to 2.1 billion in 2013.
* The United States has the largest chunk of the planet's obese population, with 13% of the global total, despite having less than 5% of the world's population.
* Obesity rates are highest in the Middle East and North Africa, with over 58% of adult men and 65% of adult women overweight or obese.
* The problem is most acute in countries such as Bahrain, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Oman, and Kuwait, where obesity rates have increased significantly.

**Causes and Consequences:**

* The study suggests that the availability of cheap, fatty, sugary, salty, high-calorie "junk food" and the rise of sedentary lifestyles are major contributors to the obesity epidemic.
* Obesity is a major risk factor for heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers, with chronic complications killing approximately 3.4 million adults annually.
* The problem is not limited to adults, with obesity rates rising nearly 50% in children and adolescents worldwide.

**Global Response:**

* The World Health Organization has launched a commission to study rising obesity among children worldwide and suggest solutions.
* The study's findings highlight the need for a global response to address the obesity epidemic, with a focus on promoting healthy diets and increasing physical activity.

**Conclusion:**

The global obesity epidemic is a pressing public health concern that requires immediate attention. The study's findings emphasize the need for a comprehensive approach to address the root causes of obesity, including the availability of unhealthy food and sedentary lifestyles. By working together, we can reduce the burden of obesity and promote healthier lifestyles worldwide.
answers: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. The 188-country study found that there are 2.1 billion overweight or obese people in the world, making up around 30% of the world's population, up from 20% in 1980, USA Today reports. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." The study published in British medical journal the Lancet found that the Middle East and north Africa had seen the biggest weight gains, though the US still has the largest number of obese people, with 87 million of the world's 671 million obese people, reports Reuters. Other countries, however, have even higher obesity rates, including Tonga, where more than 50% of all adults are obese. "Two-thirds of the obese population actually resides in developing countries," says one of the researchers; they warn that obesity rates are rising among rich and poor countries, men and women, and adults and children alike.

The letter, written after a year of separation, is said to be a heartfelt attempt by Cruise to rekindle their friendship and possibly more.

According to sources, Cruise, 51, wrote the letter as he realized that Katie, 34, would be unreceptive to a phone call. The letter is described as not being over-the-top, but rather a genuine expression of his feelings and concern for her well-being. Sources close to Holmes say that she has been "genuinely touched" by the letter and has found it cathartic.

In other news, the Internet Archive has been collecting data from Alexa Internet since 1996, adding it to the Wayback Machine after an embargo period. This data is used to preserve the internet's history and provide a snapshot of the web as it existed at a particular point in time.

Additionally, LOOK magazine is highlighting the key trends to start wearing now, including fashion picks from high street brands. The magazine also features an interview with Kristen Wiig, who apologizes for her wild past, and a warning from a royal bodyguard that Kate Middleton's baby is in danger. Furthermore, the magazine explores the world of cyber spies and reveals secrets from A-listers' make-up artists.

Overall, this week's LOOK magazine is a must-read, with a mix of celebrity news, fashion trends, and interesting stories on technology and the internet.
answers: It's been a year since Katie Holmes filed for divorce from Tom Cruise, and apparently Cruise is feeling sentimental. A source tells UK magazine Look the actor sent Holmes an "emotional letter" looking to, at the very least, be friends again, Australia's News Network reports. "It's like he's finally recognized that Katie will always be the love of his life," the source says. Even so, "It won't have been an over the top letter—it has been a year and I'm sure Tom will have been aware that Katie wouldn't be interested in running straight back into his arms." Sources close to Holmes say she was "touched" by the letter, which doesn't sound promising for Cruise. "Tom would no doubt take her back in a second, but I don't think that's what Katie wants," says one. (Just to keep things in perspective, we'll point out that Look is the sort of magazine that also runs headlines like, "Royal Bodyguard Warns: 'Kate Middleton's Baby Is In Danger!'") In other news, Huffington Post notes that it's Cruise's 51st birthday.

Canadian billionaire Barry Sherman, the founder of generic pharmaceuticals giant Apotex Inc., and his wife Honey, a philanthropist, were found dead in their Toronto mansion on Friday. The couple, both 75 and 70 years old respectively, were discovered hanging from a railing surrounding their basement lap pool. The police initially classified the deaths as "suspicious" but have since handed over the investigation to the homicide squad.

According to police, the cause of death was ligature neck compression, meaning strangulation. The couple's family has dismissed the theory that the deaths were a murder-suicide, calling it "inconsistent with the rumours regrettably circulated in the media." The family stated that the couple was known for their enthusiasm for life and commitment to their family and community.

Barry Sherman was a renowned workaholic who built his business from scratch, creating hundreds of jobs in Toronto and amassing a net worth of $4.77 billion, making him the 15th richest person in Canada. His wife, Honey, was a dedicated philanthropist who served on several boards, including the Baycrest Foundation and the York University Foundation.

The couple's friends and colleagues have described them as kind and generous, with many expressing shock and disbelief at the news of their deaths. A makeshift memorial was set up outside their home, where neighbours, Apotex workers, and well-wishers dropped off flowers in their honour.

The investigation is ongoing, with police searching for answers about the circumstances surrounding the couple's deaths. The police have stated that there were no signs of forced entry and no suspects-at-large that the public should be concerned about. The case has sparked widespread media attention, with many speculating about the possible motives behind the couple's deaths.
answers: The investigation into the mysterious deaths of a billionaire and his wife is now being led by homicide detectives, police say—suggesting the deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman were either murder-suicide or a double murder. Police, who have described the deaths as "suspicious," revealed Sunday that the cause of death for both Shermans was "ligature neck compression," a form of strangulation, the CBC reports. Sources have told the media that the couple were found hanging near an indoor pool in the basement of their Toronto mansion. Police say they haven't found any sign of forced entry, or a note that could explain what happened to 75-year-old pharmaceutical tycoon Barry Sherman and his 70-year-old wife, both renowned philanthropists. The couple's four children have rejected what they say are "rumors" that the deaths are being investigated as a murder-suicide, and many of the influential couple's friends agree. "There is absolutely zero debate in my mind, this was a double homicide," says Canadian Sen. Linda Frum, a longtime friend of the couple, per the New York Times. The Globe and Mail reports that just days before the bodies were found, Honey Sherman was enthusiastically making plans for their annual trip to Florida, emailing friends that she would be traveling to the state on Dec. 18 and Barry Sherman would join her a week later. The couple also sent out invitations last week to a dinner party at their winter home in Palm Beach.

**Egypt Holds Final Round of Voting in Parliamentary Elections**

Egyptians voted in the final round of parliamentary elections on January 3, 2012, as the country continues to transition to democracy after the ouster of former President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011. The elections are seen as a crucial step towards establishing a new government and determining the country's future direction.

**Islamist Groups Expected to Consolidate Gains**

The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice party is expected to consolidate its gains in the final round of voting, which covers nine provinces, including the North and South Sinai governorates. The Brotherhood has already taken the lead in the first two rounds of voting, with the conservative Nour party coming in second. Analysts predict that the Brotherhood may win a clear majority of seats in the new parliament, which could give it significant influence over the country's government.

**Mubarak's Trial Continues**

Meanwhile, Mubarak's trial resumed on January 2, with the chief prosecutor accusing the ousted leader of imposing "tyrannical rule" and devoting the last decade of his rule to ensure his son's succession. The prosecutor, Mustafa Suleiman, described Mubarak as a corrupt man whose lust for power will forever tarnish his legacy. Mubarak faces charges of complicity in the killing of over 800 protesters during the crackdown on the popular uprising that forced him out of office.

**Prosecutor Demands Harsh Penalty for Mubarak**

In a scathing critique of Mubarak's rule, Suleiman demanded that the former president be given the "harshest penalty" for his crimes. Mubarak's two sons, Alaa and Gamal, are also on trial, facing corruption charges. The trial is seen as a crucial test of the country's commitment to accountability and justice.

**Economic Growth Slows**

The elections and Mubarak's trial take place amid growing economic concerns, with the country's growth slowing due to the unrest and lack of investment. Foreign-currency reserves have declined by 44% to $20.2 billion, and the benchmark EGX 30 stock index has lost 49% in value last year.

**Military Rulers Face Opposition**

The new parliament is expected to take authority over the hiring and firing of a prime minister, which could lead to a confrontation with the military rulers. The Brotherhood has said it expects the parliament to take control, while the military has stated that it intends to retain authority.

**Protest
answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.

**Car Suspended from Telephone Pole after Driver Reacts to GPS Directions**

A bizarre incident occurred in Mendon on Wednesday evening when a Toyota Corolla was suspended from a telephone pole after its driver, Nabila Altahan, reacted too quickly to a GPS system's instructions. According to police, Altahan was driving westbound on Route 4 when her GPS device suddenly directed her to turn around, as she had passed her intended destination. In a swift reaction, Altahan left the road, and her car became lodged on a telephone pole's guy wire.

Fortunately, neither Altahan nor her passenger was injured in the incident. Witnesses, including a driver who happened to be passing by, reported that Altahan jumped out of the car as it was suspended from the pole. The Rutland City Fire Department and State Police responded to the scene.

This unusual incident serves as a reminder of the importance of carefully following GPS directions and not reacting impulsively to sudden changes in navigation.
answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
